title: 115_s1980
content: The "Renewable Chemicals Act of 2017" may be cited as the Renewable Chemicals Act. It introduces credits for the production of renewable chemicals and investments in renewable chemical production facilities under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Renewable Chemicals Act of 2017 introduces a production credit for renewable chemicals under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is $0.15 per pound of biobased content of each renewable chemical produced by the taxpayer or a contract manufacturer. There is a limitation on the credit amount allocated by the Secretary for each taxable year. The Renewable Chemicals Act of 2017 offers a production credit for renewable chemicals under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is $0.15 per pound of biobased content of each renewable chemical produced, with specific criteria for eligibility. The Renewable Chemicals Act of 2017 provides a production credit for renewable chemicals under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is $0.15 per pound of biobased content of each renewable chemical produced, with specific eligibility criteria. Biobased content is determined by testing representative samples using ASTM D6866, and renewable biomass is defined in the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act of 2002. National limitations on credits for renewable chemicals are outlined in section 48E(e). The Renewable Chemicals Act of 2017 provides a production credit for renewable chemicals under section 38 of the Internal Revenue Code. The credit is $0.15 per pound of biobased content of each renewable chemical produced. National limitations on credits for renewable chemicals are outlined in section 48E(e). Coordination with the Investment Credit for Renewable Chemical Production Facilities is detailed in section 48E(f). The Secretary may not allocate any credit amount under this section to any taxable year which begins more than 5 years after the date of the enactment of this section. The renewable chemicals production credit is part of the general business credit under section 38 of the Code. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a renewable chemical production facilities credit under section 46. This credit is part of the general business credit and provides incentives for renewable chemicals production. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a renewable chemical production facilities credit under section 46, providing incentives for renewable chemicals production. SEC. 48E introduces an investment credit for renewable chemical production facilities. The renewable chemical production facilities credit under section 46 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows a 30 percent credit on eligible property of a renewable chemical production facility placed in service by the taxpayer. The credit is limited to the amount allocated by the Secretary for the taxable year. A renewable chemical production facility is defined as a facility owned by the taxpayer and placed in service after a certain date. The eligible property for the renewable chemical production facilities credit must be placed in service after the enactment date, not previously credited, and used for producing renewable chemicals. The term 'renewable chemical' is defined as specified in section 45S(c)(1). Rules similar to those in section 46 apply for qualified progress expenditures. There is a national limitation on credits for renewable chemicals. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, will establish a program to allocate credit amounts for taxpayers producing renewable chemicals. The total credits allocated cannot exceed $500,000,000, with a taxpayer limit of $25,000,000 per year. The Secretary will establish a program to allocate credit amounts for taxpayers producing renewable chemicals. The total credits allocated cannot exceed $500,000,000, with a taxpayer limit of $25,000,000 per year. Selection criteria for allocations include job creation, reduced dependence on non-renewable resources. The program allocates credit amounts for taxpayers producing renewable chemicals, focusing on job creation, reduced dependence on non-renewable resources, technological innovation, energy efficiency, greenhouse gas reduction, and commercial viability. If the allocated credit exceeds the limit, redistribution occurs. The program allocates credit amounts for taxpayers producing renewable chemicals. Excess credits can be reallocated by the Secretary. The identity of the taxpayer and the credit amount must be publicly disclosed. Coordination with the Production Credit for Renewable Chemicals is required if a taxpayer makes an election under subsection. The Secretary will issue regulations for the renewable chemical production facility credit under section 45S. The credit cannot be allocated more than 5 years after enactment. Credits can be used against alternative minimum tax. The credit under section 46 attributable to the renewable chemical production facilities credit under section 48E is subject to certain limitations. Clerical amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section introduce a credit for the production of renewable chemicals and investment in renewable chemical production facilities. These changes apply to chemicals produced and facilities placed in service after the enactment of the Act.
